facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1871 of 1967

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1871 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 3rd May, 1965 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 345 of 1960

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 3rd May, 1965 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 345 of 1960.

facts.text: Temple of Shree Maharaja Ram Janki Lacchuman Maharaj is located in the village of Mauza Deogan in the State of Bihar

anchor.surface_text: the temple of Shree Maharaja Ram Janki Lacchuman Maharaj in the village of Mauza Deogan in the State of Bihar is a religious trust

facts.text: Two brothers Ram Adhikari Choudhary and Ram Lochan Choudhary and Amir Prasad Choudhary son of their brother for himself and as guardian of Ramakant Prasad Choudhary members of joint Hindu family executed a samarpannama on 17.6.1921 dedicating certain properties to the temple

anchor.surface_text: Two brothers, Ram Adhikari Choudhary and Ram Lochan Chou- dhary, and Amir prasad Choudhary, son of their brother, for himself and as guardian of Ramakant Prasad Choudhary, who were all members of joint Hindu family executed on 17.6.1921 a samarpannama by which they dedicated certain properties to the above mentioned temple.

facts.text: By the 1921 samarpannama the executants completely divested themselves of any interest in the properties except that they and members of their families were to be shebaits

anchor.surface_text: By that deed of dedication they companypletely divested themselves of any interest in the properties except that they and the members of their families were to be shebaits.

facts.text: By 1921 samarpannama five persons absolute strangers to the family were appointed panches to take rendition of accounts from the manager shebait year after year after death of executants

anchor.surface_text: By the same deed five persons, who were absolute strangers to the family, were appointed panches to take the rendition of account of the income and expenditure from, the manager, shebait for the time being year after year on the death of the, executants.

facts.text: Panches empowered to discharge manager shebait if found illegal extravagant or loss in income or property and appoint other deserving from family

anchor.surface_text: If in the opinion of the said panches the manager and shebait for the, time being be found  illeg  and extravagant or there be any loss in respect of the income of the dedicated property or the dedicated property which is at present or be acquired in future, in that case they should discharge the manager shebait for the time being and  appoint  other deserving manager, shebait, who be deemed according to the companyditions mentioned above, in his place from among the members of the family of the executants.

facts.text: Panches given power to fill up vacancies in their ranks

anchor.surface_text: The panches were given power to fill up vacancies in their ranks.

facts.text: On 7-12-1928 Ram Adhikari Choudhary executed another samarpannama endowing further properties to the temple containing similar terms but new set of five panches one from earlier set

anchor.surface_text: On 7-12-1928 Ram Adhikari Choudhary alone executed another samarpannama endowing some further properties in favour of the temple, companytaining similar terms as in the earlier samarpannama but in place of five panches mentioned in the earlier deed he appointed a fresh set of five panches, of whom only one belonged to the earlier set of panches.

facts.text: In 1928 samarpannama panches competent to dismiss shebait if fails to manage arrange ragbhog properly show negligence spoil property incur unnecessary expenses and appoint another from family

anchor.surface_text: In this deed also it was provided that if any future shebait fails to manage the dedicated properties, arrange ragbhog to the aforesaid deities properly, show negligence, spoil the property, and incur  un -necessary expenses, the said panches will be companypetent to dismiss the said shebait and appoint another one out of the members of the family of me, the executant, who happens to be honest and capable.

facts.text: On 14.7.1934 Ram Adhikari Choudhary executed ekrarnama stating he adopted Bhagwat Prasad Choudhary present first respondent and appointed him shebait and manager of all dedicated properties

anchor.surface_text: On 14.7.1934 Ram Adhikari Choudhary executed another deed called ekrarnama referring to the fact that he had adopted Bhagwat Prasad Choudhary, the present first respondent, and that he had been appointed shebait and manager of all the dedicated properties companyered by the earlier two samarpannamas.

facts.text: 1934 ekrarnama directed that stipulations in 1928 samarpannama re maintenance of accounts hold good

anchor.surface_text: He also directed that the stipulations companytained in the samarpannama dated the 7th December, 1928 in respect of maintenance of account of income and expenditure of the dedicated property, shall hold good in respect of the management of the dedicated property and maintenance of the account of income and expenditure.

facts.text: 1934 ekrarnama provided future shebait appointment practice: shebait in office appoints during lifetime or after him most capable son then male issue or brothers sons etc from family not others

anchor.surface_text: He mentioned numberhing about the panches mentioned in the earlier deed, but provided that as  to  the appointment of shebaits in future, the practice to be followed will be that the shebait in office shall be fully companypetent to  appoint  during his life time or that after him he who amongst his sons be alive and most capable shall be appointed shebait of the said deities one after another. In case there be numbermale issue in the family of the shebait in office, firstly, amongst the male issue or in case there be numbercapable man amongst the children of the aforesaid persons, the shebait in office shall be companypetent to appoint a shebait amongst the children of my companysin  fathers brothers sons  brothers, deemed to be capable. But the shebait in office is and shall number be companypetent to appoint a shebait from the family of other persons.

facts.text: Executants completely divested themselves of title to or interest in dedicated properties which became properties of the deity family thereafter only power to be shebaits and managers

anchor.surface_text: Be that as it may, we are of opinion that the main point regarding all these documents is the fact that the executants had company- pletely divested themselves of any title to or interest in the dedicated properties which thereby became the properties of the deity. The only power which the members of the family thereafter had was to be shebaits and managers of the temple.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held that the 1921 document created a trust in which the public were interested

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge who tried this suit companysidered that the 1921 document created a trust in which the public were interested.

facts.text: Patna High Court held the temple is a private endowment

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court on the other hand took the view that ... temple was meant for public purposes.

facts.text: Temple situated within independent compound walls though near the house of the founders

anchor.surface_text: the mere fact that the temple was situated within independent companypound walls, though near the house of the founders, companyld number by itself indicate that the temple was meant for public purposes.

facts.text: Family had only right to have member as manager or shebait subject to superintendence and control by body of outsiders panches with power to remove if not acting properly

anchor.surface_text: We are particularly of the view that as the only right which the family had was to have a member of the family as a manager or shebait and the shebait was subject to superintendence and companytrol by a body of outsiders, who were given the power to remove the shebait if he did number act properly, it is decisive of the question as to the public character of the temple.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds the trust is a religious trust as public are interested in it

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that on the facts of this case the trust should be deemed to be a religious trust as the public are interested in it.

facts.text: Appeal allowed judgment and decree of High Court set aside restoring judgment of Subordinate Judge

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed and the judgment and decree of the High Court set aside, restoring the judgment of the learned Subordinate Judge.

issues.text: whether the temple of Shree Maharaja Ram Janki Lacchuman Maharaj in the village of Mauza Deogan in the State of Bihar is a religious trust within the meaning of the term in section 2, clause 1 of the Bihar, Hindu Religious Trusts Act, or a private endowment

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision in this appeal is whether the temple of Shree Maharaja Ram Janki Lacchuman Maharaj in the village of Mauza Deogan in the State of Bihar is a religious trust within the, meaning of the term in section 2, clause  1  of the Bihar, Hindu Religious Trusts Act, or a private endowment.

issues.text: whether by executing the samarpannama of 7.12.1928 and ekrarnama of 14.7, 1934 Ram Adhikari Choudhary was competent to change the provisions of 1921 document

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary for the purpose of this case to go into the question whether by executing the samarpannama of 7.12.1928 and ekrarnama of 14.7, 1934 Ram Adhikari Choudhary was companypetent to change the provisions of 1921 document. It is number even clear, whether by this document he had intended to do away with the provisions companytained in the earlier documents regarding the panches and their powers.

issues.text: whether any member of the public could be said to be interested in the religious trust

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge who tried this suit companysidered that the 1921 document created a trust in which the public were interested. But in this to some extent he seems to have been influenced by a wrong reading of section 2 g  i of the Act, especially the words to participate in any religious or charitable ministration under such trust. He mistook the word ministration, to be administration. The difference between the words would make all the difference as. to whether any member of the public companyld be said to be interested in the religious trust.

issues.text: the question as to the public character of the temple

anchor.surface_text: We are particularly of the view that as the only right which the family had was to have a member of the family as a manager or shebait and the shebait was subject to superintendence and companytrol by a body of outsiders, who were given the power to remove the shebait if he did number act properly, it is decisive of the question as to the public character of the temple.

arguments.claim: The 1921 document created a trust in which the public were interested

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge who tried this suit considered that the 1921 document created a trust in which the public were interested.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the samarpannama of 7.12.1928 and ekrarnama of 14.7, 1934 Ram Adhikari Choudhary was companypetent to change the provisions of 1921 document. It is nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Influenced by misreading of section 2(g)(i) but conclusion correct based on other grounds like panches control

arguments.claim: Wrong reading of section 2 g i mistaking ministration for administration

anchor.surface_text: But in this to some extent he seems to have been influenced by a wrong reading of section 2 g i of the Act, especially the words to participate in any religious or charitable ministration under such trust.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is number even clear, whether by this document he had intended to do away with the provisions compa

arguments.court_reasoning: Word is ministration not administration; confirmed from official publication

arguments.claim: Temple situated within independent compound walls though near house of founders could not by itself indicate meant for public purposes

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court on the other hand took the view that the mere fact that the temple was situated within independent compound walls, though near the house of the founders, could not by itself indicate that the temple was meant for public purposes.

arguments.claim: Control over faqirs sadhus and occasional festivals ancillary to main purpose of puja of deity

anchor.surface_text: They further took the view that the control over faqirs, sadhus and the occasional festivals would be ancillary to the main purpose, that is, for puja of the deity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: it and the shebait was subject to superintendence and companytrol by a body of outsiders, who were given the power to remove the shebait if he did num

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees HC not incorrect on this view

arguments.claim: Panches had no opportunity to function or take part in affairs of temple and trust properties

anchor.surface_text: As regards the panches mentioned in the documents they were of opinion that they had no opportunity to function or take any part in the affairs of the temple and the trust properties,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d in the name of the deity. Half of the income from the properties was to be taken by the two waves of the, testator for their maintenance during thei

arguments.court_reasoning: Provision for panches creates public interest in management regardless of actual functioning

arguments.claim: Nothing to indicate founder intended members of public associated with management of temple trust properties and puja

anchor.surface_text: and that there was nothing to indicate that the founder or founders of the trust intended that members of the public should be associated with the management of the temple and the trust properties and the puja.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d in the name of the deity. Half of the income from the properties was to be taken by the two waves of the, testator for their maintenance during thei

arguments.court_reasoning: Appointment of outsider panches with control powers indicates public association

arguments.claim: Mere public attending festivals like Ram Navami Janmashtami does not justify inference trust created for public benefit

anchor.surface_text: They also held that the mere fact that some other members of the public might be attending festivals like Ram Navami, Janmashtami etc. does not justify the inference that the trust or temple was created for the benefit or worship of the public at large or of some considerable portion of it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: it and the shebait was subject to superintendence and companytrol by a body of outsiders, who were given the power to remove the shebait if he did num

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with HC that public worship and faqirs provision of no significance

arguments.claim: Executants completely divested themselves of title or interest dedicated properties became properties of deity family only power to be shebaits managers

anchor.surface_text: Be that as it may, we are of opinion that the main point regarding all these documents is the fact that the executants had completely divested themselves of any title to or interest in the dedicated properties which thereby became the properties of the deity.

arguments.claim: High Court judgment proceeds from failure to appreciate Deoki Nandan v Murlidhar

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the judgment of the High Court proceeds from failure to appreciate the effect of the judgment of this Court in Deoki Nandan v. Murlidhar 1956 SCR 756.

arguments.claim: Outsider panches with superintendence control and removal power over shebait decisive of public character brings within clause g section 2

anchor.surface_text: We are particularly of the view that as the only right which the family had was to have a member of the family as a manager or shebait and the shebait was subject to superintendence and control by a body of outsiders, who were given the power to remove the shebait if he did not act properly, it is decisive of the question as to the public character of the temple.

arguments.claim: Distinction from Bhagwan Din: here endowment direct to idol public user cogent evidence of public dedication

anchor.surface_text: But in the present case, as in the case of Deoki Nandan v. Murlidhar, the endowment is in favour of the idol itself and in such circumstances proof of user by the public without interference would be cogent evidence that dedication was in favour of the public.

arguments.claim: Trust is religious trust as public interested in it

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that on the facts of this case the trust should be deemed to be a religious trust as the public are interested in it.

arguments.claim: Unnecessary to decide if samarpannama 1928 and ekrarnama 1934 competent to change 1921 provisions

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary for the purpose of this case to go into the question whether by executing the samarpannama of 7.12.1928 and ekrarnama of 14.7, 1934 Ram Adhikari Choudhary was competent to change the provisions of 1921 document.

holdings.text: the trust should be deemed to be a religious trust as the public are interested in it

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that on the facts of this case the trust should be deemed to be a religious trust as the public are interested in it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act s.2 cl.(1) and s.2(g) based on outsider panches' control over shebait, following Deoki Nandan v. Murlidhar precedent distinguishing private endowments

holdings.text: the executants had completely divested themselves of any title to or interest in the dedicated properties which thereby became the properties of the deity. The only power which the members of the family thereafter had was to be shebaits and managers of the temple

anchor.surface_text: Be that as it may, we are of opinion that the main point regarding all these documents is the fact that the executants had company- pletely divested themselves of any title to or interest in the dedicated properties which thereby became the properties of the deity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretation of samarpannama deeds showing complete dedication to deity, family retains only shebait rights subject to oversight

holdings.text: as the only right which the family had was to have a member of the family as a manager or shebait and the shebait was subject to superintendence and control by a body of outsiders, who were given the power to remove the shebait if he did not act properly, it is decisive of the question as to the public character of the temple

anchor.surface_text: We are particularly of the view that as the only right which the family had was to have a member of the family as a manager or shebait and the shebait was subject to superintendence and control by a body of outsiders, who were given the power to remove the shebait if he did not act properly, it is decisive of the question as to the public character of the temple.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Outsider panches' superintendence, account-taking, and removal power over family shebait indicates public association with management

holdings.text: There could be no better indication of the fact that the members of the public were associated with the management of the temple and interest in its management was created in them, thus bringing the matter directly within clause g of section 2 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: There could be no better indication of the fact that the members of the public were associated with the management of the temple and interest in its management was created in them, thus bringing the matter directly within clause g of section 2 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Panch provisions create public interest in management satisfying s.2(g) despite no actual functioning

holdings.text: the word used is ministration and not administration

anchor.surface_text: We have called for and perused the copy of the Act as printed in the official publication and we, find that the word used is ministration and not administration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Verification from official Act text corrects lower court's misreading of s.2(g)(i)

holdings.text: the endowment is in favour of the idol itself and in such circumstances proof of user by the public without interference would be cogent evidence that dedication was in favour of the public

anchor.surface_text: But in the present case, as in the case of Deoki Nandan v. Murlidhar, the endowment is in favour of the idol itself and in such circumstances proof of user by the public without interference would be cogent evidence that dedication was in favour of the public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Bhagwan Din where grant to individual; direct to idol makes public user evidence of public dedication

holdings.text: the learned Judges of the High Court were not incorrect in their view that the fact that members of the public took part in the worship in the temple and the provision for faqirs etc was of no significance

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were not incorrect in their view that the, fact that members of the public took part in the worship in the temple and the provision for faqirs etc was of no significance,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court that public worship and faqir provisions ancillary, not indicative of public trust

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of this Court in Deoki Nandan v. Murlidhar  1956 SCR 756 . In that case the dedication of the properties was number as companylete and as categorical as in the present case. Only in the absence of male issue, the entire immovable property was to stand endowed in the name of the deity. Half of the income from the properties was to be taken by the two waves of the, testator for their maintenance during their lifetime.

precedents.cited_proposition: factors indicating public endowment such as separate building for idol, permanent installation of idols, appointment of archaka, and committee of non-relations for management
precedents.cited_holding: endowment held public despite reservations in dedication

anchor.surface_text: In Deoki Nandan v. Murlidhar this Court referred to certain facts as indicating that the endowment is to the public Firstly, there is the fact that the idol was installed number within the precincts of residential quarters but in a separate building companystructed for that very purpose on a vacant site. And as pointed out in Delroos Banoo Begum v. Nawab Syud Ashgur Ally Khan 1 , it is a factor to be taken into account in deciding whether an endowment is private or public, whether the place of worship is located inside a private house or a public building.

precedents.cited_proposition: specific facts like location of idol, permanent installation, pujari appointment indicating public nature

precedents.citation: Delroos Banoo Begum v. Nawab Syud Ashgur Ally Khan 1

anchor.surface_text: And as pointed out in Delroos Banoo Begum v. Nawab Syud Ashgur Ally Khan 1 , it is a factor to be taken into account in deciding whether an endowment is private or public, whether the place of worship is located inside a private house or a public building. Secondly, it is admitted that some of the idols are permanently installed on a pedestal within the temple, precincts.

precedents.case_name: Delroos Banoo Begum v. Nawab Syud Ashgur Ally Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: location of place of worship (inside private house or public building) is a factor in deciding if endowment is private or public

anchor.surface_text: But in the present case, as in the case of Deoki Nandan v. Murlidhar, the endowment is in favour of the idol itself and in such circumstances proof of user by the public without interference would be companyent evidence that dedication was in favour of the public. The decision of the Division Bench of the Patna High Court in Ramsaran Das v. Jai Ram Das  AIR 1943 Pat 135

precedents.cited_proposition: when endowment is directly in favour of the idol, public user is cogent evidence of public dedication

precedents.citation: Bhagwan Din v. Har Saroop  AIR 1940 PC 7

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were  1  1875 15 Bon. L R. 167, 186. number companyrect in their view that the, fact that members of the public took part in the worship in the temple and the provision for faqirs etc was of numbersignificance, and in relying upon the decision of the Privy Council in Bhagwan Din v. Har Saroop  AIR 1940 PC 7  for this purpose.

precedents.cited_proposition: mere public worship at temple does not prove dedication to public if original grant was to private individual

precedents.citation: Ramsaran Das v. Jai Ram Das  AIR 1943 Pat 135

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Division Bench of the Patna High Court in Ramsaran Das v. Jai Ram Das  AIR 1943 Pat 135  that a mere provision for the service of sadhus, occasional guests aid wayfarers in a dedication to an idol does number render the dedication substantially for public purpose must be understood in the background of that case where the properties originally stood in the names of various mahants

precedents.case_name: Ramsaran Das v. Jai Ram Das
precedents.cited_proposition: mere provision for service of sadhus etc. does not make dedication public

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed and the judgment and decree of the High Court set aside, restoring the judgment of the learned Subordinate Judge. The 1st respondent will pay the costs of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We are particularly of the view that as the only right which the family had was to have a member of the family as a manager or shebait and the shebait was subject to superintendence and control by a body of outsiders, who were given the power to remove the shebait if he did not act properly, it is decisive of the question as to the public character of the temple.
The appeal is allowed and the judgment and decree of the High Court set aside, restoring the judgment of the learned Subordinate Judge. The 1st respondent will pay the costs of the appellant.

edges.explanation: Public association with management (h4) supports holding of public interest making it religious trust (h1)
h4 indicates public interest in management, addressing whether public interested (i3)

anchor.surface_text: There could be no better indication of the fact that the members of the public were associated with the management of the temple and interest in its management was created in them, thus bringing the matter directly within clause g of section 2 of the Act.
The appeal is allowed and the judgment and decree of the High Court set aside, restoring the judgment of the learned Subordinate Judge. The 1st respondent will pay the costs of the appellant.
